reading_list.title: Constructing Quotient Inductive-Inductive Types
reading_list.author: Ambrus Kaposi, Andras Kovacs and Thorsten Altenkirch
reading_list.description: This is the first paper I read during my internship with Ambrus Kaposi. There was a lot of prerequities I was missing at the time, so the notes accompanying this is quite all over the place, but hopefully comprehensive nontheless

reading_list.title: A Modal Analysis of Staged Computation
reading_list.author: Rowan Davies and Frank Pfenning
reading_list.description: I've read between Sections 1 through 4. It's about how intuitionistic S4 gives a nice framework for analyzing computation stages. Our main focus was trying to understand the translation between the explicit and implicit system. I (should) have corresponding notes about this paper on this page.

reading_list.title: Homotopy Type Theory: Univalent Foundations of Mathematics
reading_list.author: The Univalent Foundations Program
reading_list.description: Slowly progressing through the book. We have an unofficial reading group at Oxford with individual students where we sometimes get along and talk about the contents. I (should) have corresponding notes on this page if you want to see what I've read through.

reading_list.title: Truncation Levels in Homotopy Type Theory
reading_list.author: Nicolai Kraus
reading_list.description: Has a bunch of interesting results on propositional truncation.

reading_list.title: Cellular Cohomology in Homotopy Type Theory
reading_list.author: Ulrik Buchholtz and Kuen-Bang Hou
reading_list.description: Hard paper, there's still a few things I'm missing but it is a paper that looks extremely interesting and I do want to get back to this sometime soon.

reading_list.title: Introduction to Categories and Categorical Logic
reading_list.author: Samson Abramsky and Nikos Tzevelekos
reading_list.description: Clean lecture notes for the Categories, Proofs and Processes course at Oxford. I like to learn pure categorical concepts from a mathematical perspective, but I am interested in the CS applications. I'm reading between Chapters 1.6 to 1.8 right now.

reading_list.title: Categorical Semantics of Linear Logic
reading_list.author: Paul-Andre Mellies
reading_list.description: Part of the reading list for my Master's Thesis.

reading_list.title: Linear Logic (in the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy)
reading_list.author: Stanford
reading_list.description: Part of the reading list for my Master's Thesis. Looks like a good first read on what Linear Logic is.
